awd_titl_txt: Effects of Anadromous Salmon on North Shore Stream          Ecosystems
awd_abstract_narration: For streams on the North Shore of Lake Superior, salmon are a                   recently introduced exotic species, and may be altering the                     stream ecosystems from their historic state.  Are salmon                        migrations into streams a significant source of nutrients and                   high quality organic matter for these stream ecosystems?  The                   importance of migration salmon in nutrient and organic matter                   flow through stream ecosystem components will be tested using                   experimental, comparative, and stable isotope tracer techniques.                It is hypothesized that the presence of salmon will: 1) result in               a shift away from terrestrial sources of organic matter and                     inorganic nutrients toward lake derived sources (salmon carcasses               and spawn); and 2) will alter the seasonal patterns of nutrient                 limitation.  This shift will be reflected in changes in                         periphyton, fine particle and dissolved organic carbon, grazer,                 shredder, and collector components of the ecosystem which can be                traced using stable isotopes.  It is further hypothesized that,                 3) the size of a patch of salmon carcasses determines the spatial               scale of the effect on the resource within the ecosystem.  A                    combination of experimental and comparative studies will provide                insight into the interdependence of nutrient limitation and                     nutrient and organic matter flow through these stream ecosystems.
